	<item>
		<title>Space Meeting (12/30/2012)</title>
		<link>http://interoccupy.net/sandycoord/minutes/space-meeting-12302012/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 31 Dec 2012 00:13:43 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>patricia</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://interoccupy.net/sandycoord/?post_type=minutes&#038;p=583</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h2>Space Meeting</h2>
Date: 12-30-12
Location: St. Jacobi
Facilitator: Jessica Fuest
Notes: Robin
<h3>Space Report Backs</h3>
<ul>
	<li dir="ltr"><strong>Greenpoint space</strong>– Will have space between 01/31 and Wednesday
<ul>
	<li dir="ltr">Used for volunteer orientation and intake</li>
	<li dir="ltr">2nd and 3rd floor will be turned into condos 6 mos out</li>
	<li dir="ltr">Available about 7am-10pm</li>
	<li dir="ltr">Engage community members there to volunteer (walk-in)</li>
	<li dir="ltr">Parking – single space, parking can be on McGuiness Blvd a couple blocks away</li>
	<li dir="ltr">Accessible to the G and L trains</li>
</ul>
</li>
	<li dir="ltr"><strong>Coney Island</strong>
<ul>
	<li dir="ltr">Warehouse function – 50,000 square feet</li>
	<li dir="ltr">Opening Monday for moving in supplies</li>
	<li dir="ltr">Working on plan for how space operates – right now just warehousing and comms</li>
	<li dir="ltr">Hopefully in the long-term for building materials and volunteer training, but not now</li>
	<li dir="ltr">Multi-agency: Respond &amp; Rebuild, city harvest (if we have cold storage), and other groups considering using it</li>
	<li dir="ltr">5 min walk from train, easy to drive to</li>
</ul>
</li>
	<li dir="ltr"><strong>Juan Carlos/Jacobi</strong>
<ul>
	<li dir="ltr">We can have the downstairs space for as long as needed</li>
	<li dir="ltr">Cannot use offices or upstairs space</li>
	<li dir="ltr">Evenings need to be scheduled in advance with Juan as to not double book space</li>
	<li dir="ltr">Do we need this space???</li>
</ul>
</li>
	<li dir="ltr"><strong>520 clinton</strong>
<ul>
	<li dir="ltr">Could be closed for many months, will know more when hear back from insurance company in a few weeks</li>
	<li dir="ltr">May have access to comm space in the meantime</li>
	<li dir="ltr">Mixed information regarding availability outlook</li>
	<li dir="ltr">Tomorrow (01/31) things need to be out</li>
</ul>
</li>
	<li dir="ltr"><strong>Kitchen</strong>
<ul>
	<li dir="ltr">Repair of dishwasher and replacement of boiler</li>
	<li dir="ltr">Office space can support about 5 comms people</li>
	<li dir="ltr">Father David will need about a week notice for use of sanctuary for orientations, etc.</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
<ul>
	<li>Cultivating a relationship with Father John would help us, he is down with us, has a lot of authority and connections.</li>
	<li>One of these spaces should be specifically used for volunteer training  - Greenpoint?</li>
	<li>It seems like there may still be a need for a centralized facility, but being closer (possibly under a half hour drive) to affected areas is important</li>
	<li>Greenpoint may not work for a dispatch location</li>
	<li>We need to fulfill obligations here at Jacobi and communicate to the public ahead of the change of location
<ul>
	<li>Signs need to be posted</li>
	<li>Website needs to be updated</li>
</ul>
</li>
	<li>UPS has been asked to hold deliveries until Wed, and may ask them to deliver to coney island on Thursday (John has been talking with them)</li>
	<li>Items are being returned to senders</li>
	<li>UPS is not accepting any new shipments</li>
</ul>
<h3>Rethinking Volunteer Infrastructure</h3>
<ul>
	<li dir="ltr">Moving into new spaces means restructuring our work; the old organization and processes may become obsolete.</li>
	<li dir="ltr">How centralized should volunteer intake, orientations and trainings be?
<ul>
	<li dir="ltr">People need a place to go to closer to them</li>
	<li dir="ltr">Centralized location could keep energy high/going</li>
</ul>
</li>
	<li dir="ltr">What role does the website play in engaging volunteers:
<ul>
	<li dir="ltr">improving website info to direct volunteers, online orientation  ahead of time (?), can help to get volunteers to work more efficiently</li>
	<li dir="ltr">Orientations including anti-oppression may be better in-person</li>
	<li dir="ltr">Walk-ins have decreased, we don’t know where to send them</li>
	<li dir="ltr">Scheduling could help</li>
	<li dir="ltr">Times and locations needs to be consistently updated – Badger needs to change that</li>
	<li dir="ltr">Volunteer sign-up should be front and center on page</li>
</ul>
</li>
	<li dir="ltr">General versus specialized volunteers:
<ul>
	<li dir="ltr">We need to think about which spaces can facilitate which kind of volunteers
<ul>
	<li dir="ltr">For example: Coney Island could be more specialized and Greenpoint might make sense for sending out large groups of general volunteers</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
</li>
	<li dir="ltr">Should volunteers be compensated?</li>
	<li dir="ltr">Event-based model volunteering?</li>
	<li dir="ltr">Logistics and presentation space needed</li>
	<li dir="ltr">Stop walk-in volunteers – dispatch them volunteers directly?</li>
</ul>
<h3>Wrap Up</h3>
<ul>
	<li>We need to get into Greenpoint first to assess situation before we change things here at Jacobi</li>
	<li>Keep Weekly meetings here?</li>
</ul>]]></content:encoded>

	<item>
		<title>Post to the Bulletin Board</title>
		<link>http://interoccupy.net/sandycoord/post-to-the-bulletin-board/</link>
		<pubDate>Sat, 28 Jul 2012 01:52:02 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>greggsky</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://interoccupy.net/testhub/?page_id=179</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[[gravityform id="4" name="Post to the Bulletin Board" ajax="true"]]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>179</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2012-07-27 21:52:02</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>2012-07-28 01:52:02</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>open</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>open</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name>post-to-the-bulletin-board</wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>publish</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>page</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>
		<wp:is_sticky>0</wp:is_sticky>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_edit_last</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[14]]></wp:meta_value>
		</wp:postmeta>
		<wp:postmeta>
			<wp:meta_key>_wp_page_template</wp:meta_key>
			<wp:meta_value><![CDATA[default]]></wp:meta_value>

	<item>
		<title>Wedding Registry Request Form</title>
		<link>http://interoccupy.net/sandycoord/wedding-registry-request-form/</link>
		<pubDate>Mon, 19 Nov 2012 18:57:23 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>dana</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://interoccupy.net/sandycoord/?page_id=475</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[<h1>Wedding Registery Request Form</h1>
Use this form to submit a request to be posted to one of the Amazon wedding registries.

<form  action="http://crm.interoccupy.net/civicrm/profile/create?gid=37&amp;reset=1" method="post" name="Edit" id="Edit" >
<div><input name="postURL" type="hidden" value="http://interoccupy.net/sandycoord/thanks-for-registry-request/" />
<input name="cancelURL" type="hidden" value="http://crm.interoccupy.net/civicrm/profile?reset=1&amp;gid=37" />
<input name="add_to_group" type="hidden" value="81" />
<input name="_qf_default" type="hidden" value="Edit:cancel" />
</div>
<script type="text/javascript" src="http://crm.interoccupy.net/sites/all/modules/civicrm/js/Common.js"></script>
<div id="crm-container" lang="en" xml:lang="en">
<div class="form-layout-compressed"><div class="crm-section helprow-first_name-section" id="helprow-first_name"><div class="content description">Who is requesting?</div></div><div id="editrow-first_name" class="crm-section editrow_first_name-section form-item"><div class=""><label for="first_name">  First Name <span class="crm-marker" title="This field is required.">*</span>
</label></div><div class="edit-value content"><input maxlength="64" size="30" name="first_name" type="text" id="first_name" class="form-text big required" /></div><div class="clear"></div></div><div id="editrow-last_name" class="crm-section editrow_last_name-section form-item"><div class=""><label for="last_name">  Last Name <span class="crm-marker" title="This field is required.">*</span>
</label></div><div class="edit-value content"><input maxlength="64" size="30" name="last_name" type="text" id="last_name" class="form-text big required" /></div><div class="clear"></div></div><div id="editrow-email-3" class="crm-section editrow_email-3-section form-item"><div class=""><label for="email-3">  Email <span class="crm-marker" title="This field is required.">*</span>
</label></div><div class="edit-value content"><input maxlength="64" size="30" name="email-3" type="text" id="email-3" class="form-text big required" /></div><div class="clear"></div></div><div id="editrow-phone-3-2" class="crm-section editrow_phone-3-2-section form-item"><div class=""><label for="phone-3-2">  Phone-Mobile <span class="crm-marker" title="This field is required.">*</span>
</label></div><div class="edit-value content"><input maxlength="32" size="20" name="phone-3-2" type="text" id="phone-3-2" class="form-text medium required" /></div><div class="clear"></div></div><div id="editrow-custom_134" class="crm-section editrow_custom_134-section form-item"><div class=""><label for="custom_134">  What is the item? <span class="crm-marker" title="This field is required.">*</span>
</label></div><div class="edit-value content"><input name="custom_134" type="text" id="custom_134" class="form-text required" /></div><div class="clear"></div></div><div id="editrow-custom_135" class="crm-section editrow_custom_135-section form-item"><div class=""><label for="custom_135">  Please include specifics <span class="crm-marker" title="This field is required.">*</span>
</label></div><div class="edit-value content"><textarea rows="4" cols="60" name="custom_135" id="custom_135" class="form-textarea required"></textarea></div><div class="clear"></div></div><div id="editrow-custom_136" class="crm-section editrow_custom_136-section form-item"><div class=""><label for="custom_136">  What location should this item end up at? <span class="crm-marker" title="This field is required.">*</span>
</label></div><div class="edit-value content"><input name="custom_136" type="text" id="custom_136" class="form-text required" /></div><div class="clear"></div></div><div id="editrow-custom_137" class="crm-section editrow_custom_137-section form-item"><div class=""><label for="custom_137">  What is this item needed for? <span class="crm-marker" title="This field is required.">*</span>
</label></div><div class="edit-value content"><textarea rows="4" cols="60" name="custom_137" id="custom_137" class="form-textarea required"></textarea></div><div class="clear"></div></div><div id="editrow-custom_138" class="crm-section editrow_custom_138-section form-item"><div class=""><label for="custom_138">  Select the Registry to add it to <span class="crm-marker" title="This field is required.">*</span>
</label></div><div class="edit-value content"><select name="custom_138" id="custom_138" class="form-select required">
	<option value="">- select -</option>
	<option value="520 Clinton">520 Clinton</option>
	<option value="New Jersey">New Jersey</option>

	<option value="Staten Island">Staten Island</option>
</select></div><div class="clear"></div></div></div><!-- end form-layout-compressed for last profile --> <div class="crm-submit-buttons">

    </div>

	<item>
		<title>Phase 1 of the Restore Yana Project Completed</title>
		<link>http://interoccupy.net/sandycoord/?p=600</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>patricia</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://interoccupy.net/sandycoord/?p=600</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[YANA (You Are Never Alone), Restore the Rock, and Occupy Sandy are proud to announce that the first phase of rebuilding our home in Rockaway Park, Queens is finally complete. On Friday January 11th, volunteers poured a new concrete floor, working late into the night to make sure there was a wheelchair ramp built before it set and dried.

YANA is a community center that opened its doors two weeks before Superstorm Sandy devastated the region. Its intended purpose was to train workers and bring jobs to the Rockaways, with an emphasis on green technologies. With the support of countless dedicated volunteers and solar power provided by Greenpeace, it re-emerged after the storm as an important relief site and community hub. We’ve been providing hot meals, free medical treatment, legal counseling and housing advocacy. YANA has also been a donation distribution site, trained and dispatched canvassers, construction crews and mold remediation teams throughout the peninsula.

For weeks, neighbors and volunteers have been working tirelessly to get YANA back on its feet so that it can resume its important work and contribute to the long-term recovery of the Rockaways. YANA is using passive and energy efficient building principles throughout its rebuilding process. The structure was completely gutted, dried out and treated for mold, brick walls were rebuilt and reinforced, the plumbing was redone and a new system of in-floor radiant heating was installed. This last element is an example of simple, inexpensive sustainable techniques that can help offset energy costs.

The floor is functional and beautiful, dyed with mineral pigments in deep reds and browns to match the unfinished brick wall. The hydronic (hot water) radiant heating system supplies heat directly to the floor through a series of pipes laid under the concrete. This system uses very little energy -- the thermal radiation warms every object with which it comes into contact so it limits heat transfer and breaks the constant heating and cooling cycle of traditional heating systems.

We’re literally building from the ground up. Infinite thanks to the neighbors, volunteers and donors who helped make it happen.

Now, phase 2. Join us.

YANA is located at B113th St. &amp; Rockaway Beach Boulevard. If you'd like to volunteer with us, we are open every day except Mondays and can put anyone to good use. Bring boots and warm clothes. You can also follow us at <a href="http://facebook.com/yana113" target="_blank">facebook.com/yana113</a>]]></content:encoded>
		<excerpt:encoded><![CDATA[]]></excerpt:encoded>
		<wp:post_id>600</wp:post_id>
		<wp:post_date>2013-01-13 20:30:37</wp:post_date>
		<wp:post_date_gmt>0000-00-00 00:00:00</wp:post_date_gmt>
		<wp:comment_status>closed</wp:comment_status>
		<wp:ping_status>closed</wp:ping_status>
		<wp:post_name></wp:post_name>
		<wp:status>draft</wp:status>
		<wp:post_parent>0</wp:post_parent>
		<wp:menu_order>0</wp:menu_order>
		<wp:post_type>post</wp:post_type>
		<wp:post_password></wp:post_password>

	</item>
	<item>
		<title></title>
		<link>http://interoccupy.net/sandycoord/?p=601</link>
		<pubDate>Wed, 30 Nov -0001 00:00:00 +0000</pubDate>
		<dc:creator>patricia</dc:creator>
		<guid isPermaLink="false">http://interoccupy.net/sandycoord/?p=601</guid>
		<description></description>
		<content:encoded><![CDATA[hase 1 of the Restore Yana Project completed

 

YANA (You Are Never Alone), Restore the Rock, and Occupy Sandy are proud to announce that the first phase of rebuilding our home in Rockaway Park, Queens is finally complete. On Friday January 11th, volunteers poured a new concrete floor, working late into the night to make sure there was a wheelchair ramp built before it set and dried.

 

YANA is a community center that opened its doors two weeks before Superstorm Sandy devastated the region. Its intended purpose was to train workers and bring jobs to the Rockaways, with an emphasis on green technologies. With the support of countless dedicated volunteers and solar power provided by Greenpeace, it re-emerged after the storm as an important relief site and community hub. We’ve been providing hot meals, free medical treatment, legal counseling and housing advocacy. YANA has also been a donation distribution site, trained and dispatched canvassers, construction crews and mold remediation teams throughout the peninsula.

 

For weeks, neighbors and volunteers have been working tirelessly to get YANA back on its feet so that it can resume its important work and contribute to the long-term recovery of the Rockaways. YANA is using passive and energy efficient building principles throughout its rebuilding process. The structure was completely gutted, dried out and treated for mold, brick walls were rebuilt and reinforced, the plumbing was redone and a new system of in-floor radiant heating was installed. This last element is an example of simple, inexpensive sustainable techniques that can help offset energy costs.

 

The floor is functional and beautiful, dyed with mineral pigments in deep reds and browns to match the unfinished brick wall. The hydronic (hot water) radiant heating system supplies heat directly to the floor through a series of pipes laid under the concrete. This system uses very little energy -- the thermal radiation warms every object with which it comes into contact so it limits heat transfer and breaks the constant heating and cooling cycle of traditional heating systems. 

 

We’re literally building from the ground up. Infinite thanks to the neighbors, volunteers and donors who helped make it happen.

 

Now, phase 2. Join us.





YANA is located at B113th St. & Rockaway Beach Boulevard. If you'd like to volunteer with us, we are open every day except Mondays and can put anyone to good use. Bring boots and warm clothes. You can also follow us at facebook.com/yana113]]></content:encoded>
